Title: Document automate development prerequisites
Body: This change is an attempt to make it easier to set up a development environment for ardupilot. It does 3 things: 1. Provides specific documentation of development prerequisites (what software needs to be installed). 2. Begins to automate the installation of development prerequisites (via shell scripts). 3. Provides a Vagrantfile that in combination with the script from # 2 allows anyone on OS X Windows or Linux to create a standardized development virtual machine running Linux in a few minutes. There is some documentation about setting up a development environment but it is scattered and underspecified. For example on the topic of Arduino on Linux [BuildingWithMake](https://code.google.com/p/ardupilot-mega/wiki/BuildingWithMake) just says you need "a working current Arduino install." The current ardupilot README tells you to use `make` instead of the Arduino IDE but doesn't say anything else about installing Arduino. Specific documentation is good an automated script is even better. Once a user has VirtualBox and vagrant installed these two commands are all that is required to bring up a fully functional development environment (including PX4) on OS X Windows or Linux: ``` vagrant up vagrant ssh -c "ardupilot/Tools/scripts/install-prereqs-ubuntu.sh -y" ``` Compare to the instructions at [PX4DevEnv in the wiki](https://code.google.com/p/arducopter/wiki/PX4DevEnv)--which only covers Windows. I think that having at least basic (but specific) development documentation in the repo itself is a good idea--it's right there when someone looks at the github page for the code

Title: Inertial Navigation for PX4 and Pixhawk
Body: This is an implementation and further development of the Extended Kalman Filter algorithm presented in https://github.com/priseborough/InertialNav. The filter currently utilises ~10% of the PX4/Pixhawk processing power. It has had some flight testing on PX4 installed in a Skywalker X-8 and a Pixhawk installed in a X-5 airframe with good results. Link to data from Pixhawk test in an X-5 airframe below: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6YbG6fDf0m4X01Vd0RrWEpBM00/edit?usp=sharing It has also had very limited flight testing on an Iris quadcopter running a Pixhawk. This testing has indicated that the tuning of parameters for best copter performance will likely be different from plane. There are 22 filter states in the version currently implemented: 4 x quaternions 3 x NED velocities 3 x NED positions 3 x gyro delta angle bias 1 x Z accel delta velocity bias 2 x NE wind velocity 3 x earth magnetic field vector 3 x body magnetic field vector Short term development needs are: - Add correction for AHRS_TRIM_X and Y to outputs - Tuning parameters need to be brought out to be adjustable via MAVlink - The test harness nee4s to be updated to include arming events and airspeed measurements Planned future developments include: - Addition of optical flow measurements from a PX4FLOW sensor. - Support for redundant sensors with fault detection - Further numerical optimisation

Title: PR and RFC on reorganizing includes of libraries headers
Body: Hi all this is a pullreq **but also a RFC** on reorganizing includes of libraries headers. Currently [the build system uses `make.inc` to add paths to the include path](https://github.com/diydrones/ardupilot/blob/063faa0383b2774cbf803c76e1f8d08f2b81e31f/mk/sketch_sources.mk#L34) (i.e. compiler option `-I`). This series of patches makes the build system use only one include path for libraries headers. That way a library header is included in a source file in two fashions: - If the header is in the same directory the source belongs to then the notation `#include ""` is used with the path relative to the directory containing the source. - If the header is outside the directory containing the source then we use the notation `#include <>` with the path relative to libraries folder. With that approach we have the advantage of only one search path for libraries and also a possible performance improvement in lookup time. Most of the changes were made with a script so they can be reproduced if necessary. Another good reason for applying this is that we reduce our dependency on make.inc. IMO in the future we should provide a way of not needing to define ALL libraries we want to link to a sketch because that's prone to errors. For example let's say several `example/*.cpp` files uses a library X and now X uses a new library Y. In that case **ALL** sketches that use library X must tell the linker (through make.inc) to link library Y as well. As a RFC your comments on this subjects are very welcome :)

Title: Creation of gittools
Body: Hi guys I have been working with some refactoring lately and with our policy of having separate commits per subsystem I've come to realize that a tool that creates separate commits automatically would come up handy. With that said I'd like to introduce a new tool set in Ardupilot: **gittools** - a set of tools to be used with git in this project. _The developers are not obligated to use it_ - `Tools/gittools/install.sh` is to be used if they want it in their environment. Well in summary this PR's commits do the following: - Create git hooks for policy compliance (http://dev.ardupilot.com/wiki/submitting-patches-back-to-master/). - Add a git command "extension": `git commit-subsystems` - splits added changes into commits separated by subsystem (libraries and first level directories other than "libraries"). Again the changes in this PR don't limit the developer as they have the option to use it or not. But I personally think that might be very useful in some situations. Best regards :) Gustavo Sousa

It also adds a simplified GPIO interface that is more self-contained than the previously attempted pull request #2761. We can think more about a VirtualPin solution that works for all the boards later. For the RCInput we are using a decoder that forward the decoded values to UART. There's currently no hard feelings on its format and it can be changed if needed. We also have the code for the decoder on a microcontroller that we will send soon. I'd like to get feedback on the format first. We've been constantly rebasing parts of this branch and changing it together with the HW available at the time in the past. We think this is now in good shape to be integrated and remaining bugs and improvements to be done on top. It also allows us to tackle better the next tasks for runtime configuration for Linux boards. Finally the HMC5883L driver does a rotation that should not really be in this layer. We are removing it here and will need feedback on who is using.

Title: Improvements to attitude accuracy estimation when operating without external aiding
Body: NOTE: the first patch is to enable reviewers to test in SITL and should not be pulled in as part of this PR. Testing had shown that the legacy EKF outperformed both DCM and EKF2 for attitude accuracy when operating without GPS or optical flow aiding. This was traced to differences in the fusion methos used to constraint roll/pitch and yaw drift and tuning of the filter. The second patch addresses these issues with the following changes: Instead of fusing in a constant velocity to constrain roll/pitch drift it fuses in a constant position. This reduces the attitude error induced by rapid velocity changes during indoor flight. This fusion method was already available within the filter. The more accurate 3-axis magnetometer fusion method can now be used when operating without aiding whereas previously it was only available in combination with external aiding. Setting EK2_MAG_CAL =4 can now be used to force it to be used all the time which may be be better for some users. Learning of gyro scale factors is inhibited when aiding is not available. This was done because testing showed that this learning was not reliable in the absence of external aiding. This patch has been tested on a Iris+ and bebop2 with GPS disabled. Here are graphs comparing roll and pitch outputs for the EKF (EKF1) EKF2 (NKF1) and DCM (AHR2) solutions from the bebop2 test with EK2_MAG_CAL=4. EKF2 and EKF are similar however DCM does not return to level immediately after recovery from a manouevre. The noticeably degraded DCM behaviour is not evident in the Iris+ logs indicating that there may be some board specific data processing issues to be resolved. ![pitch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529536/b08c46d8-c20e-11e5-8b27-cbb9429ce297.png) ![roll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529537/b0e85b08-c20e-11e5-9602-e5711e5a671c.png) Height innovations are lower than for the old EKF so alt hold stability should be improved over the baseline. ![height innovations](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529590/dc357924-c210-11e5-883d-98114ea2133d.png) The normalised innovations were generally low (see below) ![normalised innovations](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529549/65401c3a-c20f-11e5-869e-44a7fde0a889.png) however inspection of the magnetometer innovations provides evidence of a time alignment error between the magnetometer and imu data within the filter. The filer assumes the mag data is delayed 60msec relative to the imu data a value that was determined from testing on a pixhawk board and is probably not optimal for the bebop hardware. ![magnetometer innovations](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529569/eb85d0f0-c20f-11e5-9087-081d10666acf.png) Compare this to a flight without GPS from an Iris+ fitted with a Pixhawk ![iris magnetometer innovations](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3596952/12529584/5d385254-c210-11e5-86e0-866de1eaa3fb.png)

Title: Waf support Clang
Body: Following the initial work of @8W9aG and with the precious help from @lucasdemarchi I've made compilation with Clang in Waf possible not only for native targets but also for cross-compilation. To use Clang you have two options: - define the environment variables CC and CXX - use the flags _--check-c-compiler=clang_ and _--check-cxx-compiler=clang++_ in the configure stage of Waf The flags take priority over the env vars. These can also be used for GCC but Waf will default to that. For cross-compiling you need to have: - somewhere in the system the GCC toolchain for the board to be build - have the bin folder of that toolchain in the PATH environment variable This has only been tested with a specially modified sitltest target in Travis (https://travis-ci.org/OXINARF/ardupilot/builds/114686931) so testing in actual boards is really needed. I haven't worked much with Python and although I've been watching the development of the Waf build system here in Ardupilot I know very very little about Waf. Because of that input from @guludo is really requested here. Specifically: - I don't quite like the way of detecting the compiler at the board configure_env but the compiler is only detected after that so I couldn't see how to do it in another way. I though of changing the order but I'm not sure if that's possible - the function to help detect the toolchain path isn't bullet proof (for example a double symlink wouldn't work) but I felt the work to do that would be too high for the reward Ccache for Clang isn't setup in CI at the moment because it wasn't working properly with it - I'll leave that for future work. **Clang 3.4.2 at least is needed but this was only tested with version 3.7**

Title: Copter Add support for dual rotor tandem and transverse helicopters
Body: Adds support for dual-rotor tandem (CH-47 Chinook) and transverse (V22 Osprey sans tilt) helicopters: - Abstracts traditional helicopter code by moving the single rotor swash calculations and tail-rotor yaw control into AP_MotorsHeli_Single. - Abstracts rotor control (run-up/ramp-up) into AP_MotorsHeli_RSC which is used both for main rotors and direct-drive variable pitch tail-rotors. - Adds AP_MotorsHeli_Dual motor implementation supporting tandem and transverse using differential-collective-pitch for roll/pitch and mixing yaw into the two rotor swashes. - Adds HELI_DUAL_FRAME as a new frame. - Fixed the arming checks making sure that the (main and tail) rotors are spun up.

Title: Waf support Clang v2
Body: This is the v2 version of the PR #3722 Changes from that version are: - rebased on master - toolchain and compiler tools are now loaded by boards and before configuring the environment (this allows detection for compiler flags to be done in a standard way) - fixed bug in boards configure - toolchain is now a class attribute instead of define in the environment - CC/CXX environment variables can't be used to select Clang now you can only use the _--check-c/cxx-compiler_ flags - PX4 builds aren't supported (because it imports compiler flags from PX4Firmware that aren't supported by Clang) @guludo I tried to directly load the tools to choose which one we wanted in case of non-native but it wasn't pretty both in code and in display. Doing it that way means we are replacing the compiler_c/cxx tools and in that case and since we are using our own waf module what should be done is to directly integrate toolchain support in each tool. I think the way it is done now is the best: it defaults to GCC if no flag is passed just like now. If the flags are passed it checks if it is GCC or Clang making the necessary changes for each. If it isn't any of them it doesn't do anything and let the tools do their work. You can use CC/CXX env vars to change the binary even in GCC/Clang cases satisfying @lucasdemarchi request. For last **two important points** I missed to make in the previous PR: - Clang 3.4.2 at least is needed but this was only tested with version 3.7 - The toolchain support for Clang assumes you are using an unzipped version and not a toolchain installed via a package manager

Title: Copter motor library refactor
Body: There remains a parameter conversion issue which means this PR should not be immediately accepted into master. It's submitted so the peer review from other developers can start. All feedback more than welcome! This patch includes the following changes primarily to the AP_Motors library: - AP_Motors library accepts throttle input in the range 0 ~ 1 - AP_Motors lib accepts roll pitch and yaw in the range -1 ~ +1 - AP_Motors lib accepts desired-spool-state which determines whether the motors should be shut-down set to the spin-when-armed speed or spin within the regular flight range (min-throttle -> max-throttle). This allows the caller to provide the throttle input in the 0~1 range instead of having to account for the dead-zone from 0 to spin-when-armed that previously existed. - Tricopter stability patch changes to compensate for the lean angle of the rear propeller - Tricopter servo object moved from main vehicle to AP_MotorsTri class - Single and Coax motor mapping changes (servos 1 ~ 4 motors 5 & 6) - Single and Coax frames compensate for change in effective thrust from flaps as throttle changes - Single and Coax servo objects moved from main vehicle to AP_MotorsTri class - Traditional Helicopter servo objects moved from main vehicle to AP_MotorsHeli_Single class - Attitude control PIDs from from main vehicle parameter list to attitude control library

Title: Copter terrain following
Body: This is a first attempt at adding terrain following and absolute altitude handling to Copter. I'm submitting it here to get some initial feedback. The way it works is: - set TERRAIN_USE parameter to "1" to enable the use of terrain data for LAND and RTL modes - AUTO and GUIDED modes always accept terrain altitudes (regardless of the TERRAIN_USE parameter's value) if the command's MAV_FRAME is set to MAV_FRAME_GLOBAL_TERRAIN_ALT (see http://mavlink.org/messages/common) We have the following issues remaining: - the vehicle can get stuck or skip over a command if terrain data is not available for the segment's end point or at some point along the segment. I think we need to create a new version of the AP_Terrain library's height_amsl call that accepts an "extrapolate" parameter so that we can always get a terrain altitude for a given location. This might allow removing some of the code that's been added to allow propagating the failure-to-get-terrain-alt up to the top level vehicle code. - the vehicle can land hard (i.e. not slowdown to the LAND_SPEED of 50cm/s) if the home altitude appears to be 10m higher than the terrain (there's not specific link between the home altitude and the terrain altitude). Simply setting the ahrs.home.alt to the terrain alt won't work I think. - do-set-roi does not yet accept terrain altitudes - with some more effort we should be able to remove all calls to the position_vector.cpp functions

Title: EKF2 reduce vulnerability to faster in flight Z accel bias changes

Title: RFC Add AP_Module library for loadable modules
Body: This is a prototype of loadable module support for ArduPilot. The motivation for this work was that Parrot wants to be able to get the quaternion state into an external program that does digital image stabilisation of their video stream. I didn't want to do a Parrot specific hack so I thought this would be a good time to add loadable modules to allow vendors to hook into ArduPilot. The hooks available in this implementation are very restricted. This does not allow the module to call any functions in ArduPilot. Instead the module may include hook() functions which ArduPilot calls when specified events happen. Initially there are just 3 possible hooks: - when setup() is called - when setup() is complete - every time AHRS::update() completes Each hook receives hook specific data. The first two just get the current time. The AHRS update hook gets a pointer to a AHRS_state structure containing a public copy of the key AHRS state data. That should be sufficient for video stabilisation. If we add this in then we need to discuss the license on modules. The default would be that modules would need to be under GPLv3. Given that this module API doesn't allow for general purpose extension of ArduPilot and only allows for very specific hooks we could consider allowing modules under other licenses. I'd be interested in hearing feedback on that. The PR includes a very simple example module. Note that the module deliberately does not depend on the ArduPilot build system or any ArduPilot includes except for AP_Module_Structures.h. It is also written in C not C++. The idea is that AP_Module_Structures.h would be our public ABI definition for modules and would be stable (and versioned). So modules would have a good chance of working with newer versions of ArduPilot. Modules are found by adding a --module-directory option to ArduPilot. It then tries to open all *.so files in that directory and looks for the hook symbol names using dlsym(). The module system currently only works with HAL_Linux but could be make to work on other platforms if need be in the furure.

Title: RC_Channel split
Body: This is a PR for splitting RC_Channel into two libraries. RC_Channel for inputs and SRV_Channel for outputs. The result is that users can set MIN/MAX/TRIM separately on inputs and outputs. Other key features: - any output function can be assigned to any channel. The first 4 output channels are no longer special - combines all RC_Channel objects into one RC_Channels object simplifying use of RC_Channels - most output functions are controlled by function not by channel number - removes use of special RC_Channel objects in some AP_Motors classes - input channels no longer need to match output channels on plane and rover - the RCn_REV parameters are now RCn_REVERSED which is 0 for not reversed 1 for reversed (each to understand than -1 for reversed 1 for not reversed) This PR will require a lot of very careful review and testing. I expect there will be quite a few changes needed. update: automatic parameter upgrade logic has now been added update2: this now includes merging all copter builds except heli into one build. So we end up with just 2 copter binaries. This also means coax single and tricopter are all in the standard build. update3: auto-migration of heli and tricopter parameters now done I believe this PR is now ready for master (pending review)

Title: Addition of ArduSoar to ArduPlane
Body: This change adds support for autonomous soaring to Arduplane by introducing the Ardusoar library. Ardusoar was originally written by Sam Tabor and Peter Braswell and described here: https://github.com/samuelctabor/ardupilot/wiki/Ardusoar:-Soaring-fork-of-ArduPlane. I simply took that code modified it very slightly integrated it with up-to-date Arduplane (Sam's code is based on Arduplane 3.2) and tested it via SITL in X-Plane and on three different "live" RC glider models. The soaring controller is activated with an ArduPilot parameter SOAR_ACTIVE -- if it is set to 0 the drone is controlled by the regular ArduPlane logic. In this regard I don't expect this addition to cause regressions in ArduPlane's functionality. Please let me know what you think. Cheers Andrey

Title: Deprecate EKF1 and replace with EKF3 for new feature evaluation
Body: This has been tested using a pixhawk 2.1 on an Iris with range beacon only and GPS + Optical flow modes of operation. Tuning of the EKF3 is preliminary and provides equivalent innovation sequences. EKF3 uses 24 states the same as EKF2 . EKF 3 uses essentially the same interfaces and data buffers and control logic as EKF2. EKF3 makes the following changes to the state vector: - The 3 attitude error states are replaced with a direct quaternion representation (4 states) - The XYZ gyro scale factor states are removed - The Z axis accel bias is extended to include X and y axes This is expected to provide a more accurate attitude solution for the majority of use cases but does lose some of the ability to recover from extreme attitude errors caused by bad IMU data. At the moment it exceeds the flash space 1MB build limit that the build system applies to all Pixhawk 2 and lower boards regardless of capability so a temporary change to the PX4Firmware has been made to enable it to be built for the Pixhawk 2.1.

Title: Travis prepare for Trusty and other improvements
Body: Tomorrow Travis will start changing the default image from Ubuntu Precise (12.04) to Ubuntu Trusty (14.04) so I spent a bit of time testing if our builds worked with it. The only thing I discovered was that the *.profile* script in Trusty is way bigger than in Precise and it was making even the Linux builds exceed the log size (we can always view the raw log but the colorful one is better). We include the profile both in configure and build phases so I simply changed the build phase to do `set -x` after profile is included: we still log what the profile does but only one time. I've also updated the ccache version from 3.2.5 to 3.3.4 which supposedly does an even better job. Last but not least I've split the param parse check for each vehicle. @WickedShell found out that Travis wasn't complaining even when a parameter group path was wrote wrong and didn't exist but calling the script individually for each vehicle works - it is known that the param_parse.py script has issues with doing all vehicles at once so this wasn't completely surprising. The test this is now working is at https://travis-ci.org/OXINARF/ardupilot/jobs/254582098#L1571 I've added a `--no-emit` option to the script so that in CI we don't lose time emitting the documentation we only need validation. P.S.: I also played a bit with the new stage feature of Travis but I think it has more disadvantages than advantages and being in beta doesn't look to work well yet: https://travis-ci.org/OXINARF/ardupilot/builds/254589573

Title: build fix link check
Body: This reverts commit 6747f42986f4110a2e279fe72dd3126a4e278634. This broke the link to external libraries since it won't define the HAVE_* variable anymore. When we call the check method from pkg-config it defines this variable for us but it's reverted by the call to cfg.env.revert(). We could define it again but the whole check defeats the purpose of relying on the pkg-config module from waf. If the module is not sufficient it should be fixed in the proper place. This however points a deficiency on our infra: we don't have support for the user to point to a sysroot. This would make it much easier to cross-compile the packages and not have issues regarding wrong libraries. For now only the revert is done. Thanks to Miguel Arroyo for help debugging it.

Title: CI greatly reduce Make builds merge Travis jobs and move some to Semaphore
Body: After two weeks of testing several options this gives us the best total running times while reducing Travis parallel jobs to half - that leaves one free job that should also allow PRs to be analyzed faster. Make builds are only done: - for PX4-v3 always - when a cron job is started (once everyday) for all PX4 boards plus SITL I wanted to only do Make builds on the cron job but @WickedShell and @tridge wanted one PX4 board to stay so this is the best we have. All Linux boards are no longer built by Make since it has been deprecated for many months. Support for it is even about to be removed (#6816). Make builds generate enormous ccache databases so that has been removed since it gave more time downloading and uploading the ccache then it speedup the build. A huge improvement was deciding number of jobs based on number of CPUs - reduced build time for Make by a little more than half. ccache max sizes were also too big so they have been reduced. Once this is merged I'll reset all caches in Travis so they are re-generated and we spend less time downloading and uploading Travis cache. Given that the total run time is the most important stat for us (for a PR to pass all jobs have to pass so it doesn't matter if one job takes 1 minute if another will take 10 minutes better to have both take 6 minutes) PX4-v1 and PX4-v4pro are moved to Semaphore - this increases the time Semaphore jobs will be occupied (while still staying under total time) but frees one job in Travis which have more of them to run. Once this is merged I'll add these two targets to Semaphore. After this longest runner should always be the SITL test. @WickedShell is looking at ways for us to reduce its time. I'm still uncertain that saving the ccache database in Travis is worth it (and not prejudicial) but it is hard to test in a personal repo I don't get all the daily PRs ArduPilot does. So I've let it for now and I'll monitor builds in the next month. **PLEASE DON'T MERGE THIS** (but do make comments) I want to do it so I can do the necessary changes after it's merged and monitor the builds in the following hours.

Title: Copter terrain following 2nd attempt
Body: Second attempt at adding terrain following and absolute altitude handling to Copter. The way it works is: - set TERRAIN_USE parameter to "1" to enable the use of terrain data for LAND and RTL modes - AUTO and GUIDED modes always accept terrain altitudes (regardless of the TERRAIN_USE parameter's value) if the command's MAV_FRAME is set to MAV_FRAME_GLOBAL_TERRAIN_ALT (see http://mavlink.org/messages/common) This version resolves these issues found in the previous PR: 1. vehicle no longer gets stuck if terrain data is not available on it's way to a waypoint (it now extrapolates the data based on whatever terrain data it has) 2. vehicle no longer lands hard (i.e. not slowdown to the LAND_SPEED of 50cm/s) if the home altitude is far from the terrain altitude (added "correct" parameter to AP_Terrain::height_amsl to account for this). We have the following issues remaining: a) need to test how missions respond when the vehicle cannot get the terrain data for the next waypoint (it may skip the command) b) now that the extrapolation seems to work we may be able to remove some of the vehicle code added that propagates failures to get terrain data (see AC_WPNav::update). c) do-set-roi does not yet accept terrain altitudes

Title: AC_PrecLand Add buffer parameter and correlate timestamps rebased
Body: â€¦fixes #6297 #5959 This adds a 'PLND_BUFFER' parameter that can be used to set the length of an inertial buffer within AC_PrecLand. This was previously fixed at 20ms and fixed to use the last available inertial frame so effectively locked the latency between the two systems (Flight Controller and Measurement Sensor) to 20ms and appears to have been set to work with the IRLock system. However most visual systems using the companion backend will typically have latencies more in the 50-200ms range and so the attitude compensation is applied to long-lost inertial frames and causes dangerous behaviour. The PLND_BUFFER now influences the length of this buffer and is set to 20ms by default so will behave in the same way as before but it can be setup up to 250ms (and the buffer is changed immediately if the parameter is changed) to allow slower/higher latency systems. In addition this commit also now honours the 'time_usec' field of LANDING_TARGET mavlink message and extends AC_PrecLand to consume this timestamp in a way that other backends can also be extended to use (_backend->get_los_timestamp()). If the timestamp is set it attempts to correlate the closest inertial frame to the sensor frame. If it cannot correlate the frames (if the frame is out of bounds of the inertial buffer) the measurement is ignored. If the timestamp is not set it continues the previous behaviour of blindly using the oldest inertial frame. In conjunction with the earlier TIMESYNC work this should now allow AC_PrecLand to automatically adjust to latencies dynamically if the backend provides a synchronised measurement timestamp. vision_landing (https://github.com/fnoop/vision_landing) is such a system. This is not a perfect finished system yet by any means. There are still numerous issues to address but this gets us one (or two) steps closer. A few notes: - Changes inertial buffer from the fixed-at-compile-time AP_Buffer to AP_HAL RingBuffer which can be changed on the fly uses recent PR #6963 - Debug output is present will remove in a subsequent commit - TIMESYNC/MAVlink mechanism is very sub-optimal huge jitter and latency inherent. Needs improving (PR to come) - The sending sensor (companion computer/camera) is still responsible for capturing a synchronised timestamp at the time of frame capture

Title: Build Use posixpath for compatibility with Windows PX4 Toolchain MSYS git
Body: The `add_git_hashes.py` script used `os.path` to join filenames. When building ArduPilot from the PX4 toolchain on Windows this resulted in a fatal error from `git` when adding hashes to the PX4 file as it assumes POSIX paths are used. This bug only arises if the submodule's `.git` file contains a relative path. If an absolute path is used in the `.git` file `git`'s POSIX path assumption is not reached. There seems to be some murkiness about the behaviour of `git` with submodule `.git` files. It seems that the default was absolute paths until somewhere around version 1.7.10 [[1]](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8925564/git-submodule-absolute-worktree-path-config) later versions may default to relative paths. It is definitely the case that version `2.15.0.windows.1` results in relative paths while version `1.7.9.msysgit.0` (as contained in the PX4 toolchain for Windows) results in absolute paths.

Title: Copter Plane Rover Sub implement User access control over settings
Body: Hi When making commercial grade UAVs it would be very useful to implement an user access control system over settings. Main purpose is to make a veichle's settings hidden to end user to avoid him to mess up things. Also some regulators asks to guarantee UAV configuration integrity before release of certain "permit to fly". Also this function is very important to make sure an "attacker" could not connect to telemetry while flying and take over control of the legit pilot/GS. One simple method would be to just make saving settings after input a password/pin. One more sophisticated one would be having an authentication method which could let configure different user levels. It'd be very useful for commercial operations to implement a "geo"-like limitation functions but open to be customized to the actual local regulations. One example - Guest (optional): can fly but very limited height distance and no auto. Can configured also as no-operation allowed if not auth (so system is protected from airborne takeovers by telemetry channel) - Authenticated user: can fly any area and auto modes but cannot modify settings (or a subset of it). User has to input his password (one time). - Admin user: can do everything. have to input an admin password (everytime). policies should be freely customized of course. Password could be saved encrypted into flash or onto SD card. Changing it would require physical access to the SD so i think it's quite safe to do so.

Title: OS free F4Light HAL
Body: Rather simple OS-less HAL for almost any F4 board with easy portability and sub-quant scheduling accuracy. Features: * HAL don't uses any OS it does OS functions itself * separated CCM stacks for ISR and tasks * 0.8uS context switch time (thanks ScmRtOS) * ~1.5uS time from interrupt to resuming task that was waiting that interrupt * all work with task list and semaphores occures in ISR level via SVC so there is (almost) no need to disable interrupts and interrupts never disabled for more than 4 commands * priority system allows to set up "relative speed" for tasks high-priority task do not blocks out low-priority task but only slows it down * overclocking support up to 240MHz (parameter) F4 is really faster than F7! * ArduCopter loop at 1KHz without issues mean scheduling error is only 10uS - 10 times less than task tick! * SoftwareSerial driver based on ST appnote - almost any 2 pins can be used as UART * Timer based SoftI2C driver that works in interrupts allows to use any 2 pins as I2C bus * waiting for SD-card answers does in ISR as finite state machine with no CPU load * ability to prevent dumb waiting loops from stealing CPU Also: * Support for OSD on Omnibus boards * support Ardupilot parameters on builtin OSD (still untested though) * two RC inputs with automatic parsing of PPM DSM SUMD and SBUS (both inverted and non-inverted) on each allows to use 2 RC receivers in diversity mode * support for Clock Security System - if quartz fails in air then system will switch to use HSI instead * EEPROM emulation provides reilable data storage even at power failures * Parameters support for HAL to tune its functions * Supported natively OneShot125 and OneShot42 with high precision * failsafe on receiver's hangup - if no channel changes in 60 seconds (parameter) * free configuration of unused pins * USB virtual port can be connected to any UART - eg. for OSD or 3DR modems setup * any UART can be connected to ESC for 4-way interface for ESC programming * FlexiPort can be switched between UART and I2C (parameter) * Compensated frequency error for the PWM outputs * support for reading from SD card via USB (parameter) FC can be mounted deep in body. * internal flash chip is formatted to FAT and allows access via USB too * I2C_Mgr prevents creating of same device on same bus - to prevent autodetection misses like MS5611 (already initialized) detected as BMP_085 thus allows autodetection of all baro and compass types * EEPROM save can be deferred up to disarm * Prioritized SPI DMA transfers to prevent [such issues](https://github.com/betaflight/betaflight/issues/2631) * no concurrent DMA2 usage to avoid [chip bug](https://blog.frankvh.com/2012/01/13/stm32f2xx-stm32f4xx-dma-maximum-transactions/) * ability to use PPMn input port as RX-only UARTs * MAVlink messages about SD card errors * DSM decoder sends rssi as last channel * TimeZone HAL parameter - log times are localtime * and many more Sorry this PR don't follow rules and changes a lot of files but it too hard to split it out. Moreover all changes outside HAL are small and straitforward.

Title: New Board PocketPilot
Body: This PR add support for a new board called [PocketPilot](https://github.com/pocketpilot). It is a smaller version of the [BBBmini](https://github.com/mirkix/BBBMINI). It's a project from @shervinemami @patrickpoirier51 and @mirkix. PocketPilot is a cape for the small [PocketBeagle](https://beagleboard.org/pocket) a 25$ Linux board with 1GHz CPU 512MB RAM 2Ã—32-bit 200-MHz programmable real-time units (PRUs). The PocketPilot will offer: * 6 * PWM * 3 * Serial * 2 * I2C * Multi protocol RC input * Status LEDs * Buzzer output * ADC * USB * JST-GH connectors (Dronecode standard) * Size about 56mm x 35mm * Debian Linux with 4.14 RT Kernel * Open Hardware The PCB is not ready yet but we have a first successful test flight with a prototype board by @patrickpoirier51 https://youtu.be/BBnUvO6x0oY.

Title: SLCAN support Serial Line CAN as Passthrough for HW CAN and also extra CAN Port
Body: To Setup SLCAN Routing following steps should be carried out: * Ensure the CAN Bus that needs to be routed is enabled * Set CAN_SLCAN_CPORT to the CAN Driver number that should be routed. * Set CAN_SLCAN_SERNUM to the serial number to which the SLCAN packets will be routed to and from. * Set CAN_SLCAN_TIMOUT to the timeout after which the SLCAN routing will be paused and Default protocol turned back after close command is received. Note that changing CAN Port or Serial port to anything other than set the first time require a reboot. UAVCAN_GUI_TOOL can be used to setup devices connected to Ardupilot https://uavcan.org/GUI_Tool/Overview/

Title: Tools allow uploader py to detect ttyS on Ubuntu on Windows WSL
Body: WSL (Ubuntu on Windows) calls it's serial ports /dev/ttyS* and there is no /dev/serial/ so auto detection doesn't work if we don't specify ttyS* like we do in Cygwin. Note the "platform" still shows "linux" so we have to check for a version. It may be worthwhile to just add /dev/ttyS* all the time as long as that doesn't mess up linux. Also note there's /dev/ttyS1 -> /dev/ttyS128 and since the sleep was (0.05) once a device is found and a set to bootloader command is sent the bootloader actually runs then launches the app again before we loop back around to detect it in the bootloader. I shortened the timer so that we loop the list faster.

Title: Airspeed failure detection
Body: One of the outstanding items in our risk assessments is that if the airspeed sensor is producing erroneous values either through an obstruction to the pitot tube or otherwise there is a high probably this will lead to the loss of the aircraft. As the aircraft can still fly safely with just the tecs controller and no airspeed sensor data a sensible risk mitigation seems to be to detect when the vehicle is getting erroneous airspeed sensor data and revert to TECS control. After researching through the historic Issues and pull requests around this issue its clear that a generic solution to the problem is quite difficult. The solution I have put together compares multiple airspeed sensors to each-other if the sensor readings diverge it will mark divergent sensors as unhealthy and disable them. In the case of 2 sensors this results in the airspeed data being rejected as soon as there is a variance between the two sensors. In the case of 3 or more airspeed sensors individual airspeed sensors are rejected as invalid and the majority vote wins when selecting the true value to report on to TECS.

Title: In flight dynamic FFT analysis
Body: This is a port of the betaflight dynamic FFT analysis that they use to dynamically adjust filter frequencies in flight. This port currently only exposes the analysis as a log message allowing the user to see the calculated motor peak frequency via the FTUN log message. The betaflight implementation was flawed in many ways and this implementation is substantially better and more configurable. The features are fully optional and can be controlled through hwdef. I have tested this on a Pixracer and KakuteF7. I have changed the build flags to appropriately optimize for the available target MCU. The analyzer is controlled via the variables: ``` FFT_ENABLE - set to 1 to enable FFT_MINHZ - the minimum frequency for analysis FFT_MAXHZ - the maximum frequency for analysis FFT_SAMPLE_MODE - the desired sample frequency 0 for gyro rate 1 for fastloop rate 2 for fastloop/ 2 etc FFT_WINDOW_SIZE - the FFT window size large values give more resolution but higher CPU load FFT_WINDOW_OLAP - the FFT window overlap percentage for each analyzed frame FFT_FREQ_HOVER - the learned hover frequency FFT_THR_REF - the learned throttle ref value for harmonic notches (see HNTCH_THR_REF) FFT_SNR_REF - the SNR level in dB at which the FFT energy is above the calibrated noise to be considered a signal FFT_ATT_REF - attenuation value in dB to use for calculating bandwidth FTT_BW_HOVER - learned bandwidth in Hz at hover INS_HNTCH_MODE=4 will drive the harmonic notch using the FFT support ``` The analyser uses the ARM CMSIS DSP library to do the calculations it will only work on ChibiOS on M4 and M7 chips which I believe all AP supported chips are. To update the CMSIS module you must have git-lfs installed. https://help.github.com/en/articles/installing-git-large-file-storage

Title: Hold CS pins high in bootloader fixes param reset issue
Body: This fixes the param reset issue related to #13621 and #13581 The issue with param reset was finally tracked down to not holding the FRAM CS pin high in the bootloader. Electrical noise on the SPI bus while in the bootloader could cause the FRAM to become corrupt if the CS pin is floating. This has been confirmed by one user (Luke Wylie) who was able to reproduce the issue reliably. With the bootloader updated with this fix the issue can no longer be reproduced. Many thanks to Luke for doing so much testing of this issue for us!

Title: Added PARAM and SYS virtual filesystems
Body: This adds new @PARAM and @SYS virtual filesystem backends. It allows for fast parameter download via @PARAM/param pck and download of thread information in @SYS/threads.txt An easy API for adding new @SYS/ files is provided Notes: - param.pck supports URI options for start and count allowing for partial download of parameters for example @PARAM/param.pck?start=100&count=10 - header has magic value and the number of parameters to expect plus the total number of parameters - the ftp client must use the same read size for all reads for a given file handle. This is what allows us to guarantee no overlap of values with block boundaries This PR also fixes bugs in the ftp server implementation and fixes bugs in the maintenance of the parameter count in AP_Param Stack overflow logging is also added working like this: - if disarmed then we panic with a message saying what thread got the stack overflow - if armed we continue but log an internal error and put the thread name in the persistent data for watchdog

Title: WIP SensorHub
Body: This PR will contain all SensorHub related commits & comments. This is part of the Google Summer of Code 2017. # Sensor Hub A [sensor hub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensor_hub) is a computing unit that manages sensors. Its purpose is to help offload this work from a central computing unit. This can be done for a number of reasons whether it be due to cost or performance. Whatever the reason this feature will allow ArduPilot to be increase its flexibility. ## Overview ![overview](http://i.imgur.com/SYRnduo.jpg) There are two central components in this architecture: - **Source** The computing unit that manages sensors. Its responsibility is to properly setup and query sensors for their data. This data is then forwarded to the sink using a defined protocol. - **Sink** The central computing unit. It uses the data from the *source* for the main flight control tasks. Control actions (aka PWM outputs) from the sink are sent to the source so that they may be in turn sent to the motors. Communication between the *source* and *sink* can happen over UART or any other available transport. ## Protocol The sensor hub architecture calls for a message format to exchange information between the source and sink. A first version of the protocol is defined in `Protocol.h`. The packet format is as follows: ``` | Header | Message Data | CRC | ``` --- **Design Choices** - To reduce stress on the communication channel between source and sink some message types purposefully scale and limit precision of certain data values. This is of most importance for messages that occur frequently such as the `GyroMessage` and `AccelMessage`. - Timestamps are omitted from the header. If a particular message type requires to know the time it should include it in its body. - The header sequence number allows us to detect packet loss. Currently this is a `uint16_t` but in the future can be possibly reduced to a `uint8_t` depending on the window of packet loss that needs to be detected etc. - The header includes the message length and version. We could get rid of one or the other depending on how it will most likely be used in the future. For now both are still included in the header. - There are no endianness conversions. The assumption is that the sink and source have the same endianness. This may need to be revised in the future depending on the supported hardware. ## Architecture - `Protocol.h` This contains all the underlying protocol functionality i.e. encode/decode packets. - `AP_SensorHub.h` Library for processing SensorHub messages. This library orchestrates the sensor hub functionality tying together the I/O and message dispatching. - `AP_SensorHub_IO.h` Defines the IO interface necessary to read and write packets. Currently there is only one implementation `AP_SensorHub_IO_FileDescriptor.h` that operates on a raw file descriptor. - `AP_SensorHub_Handler.h` Defines the interface for message dispatching. Each `AP_*_SensorHub` backend (eg. `AP_Baro_SensorHead.h`) defines its own handler. The handler processes the raw message data correcting any scaling etc. - `AP_SensorHub_Debug.h` This defines a number of useful macros that enable various debugging options. - `SensorHub_Source` A new vehicle type is introduced to support this feature. The `SensorHub_Source` is a lightweight vehicle instance that only set's up sensor libraries and drivers. It has no additional overhead from main flight control components as the *sink* is responsible for that functionality. ### Flow The following diagrams describe the code flow for both the reading/writing of messages respectively. #### Read ![read_flow](http://i.imgur.com/UF9cclG.jpg) #### Write This is for the `AccelMessage` but other messages work similarly. ![write_flow](http://i.imgur.com/1UhakyX.jpg) ## How to Use This feature has been implemented such that it is independent of the underlying board. As a result any board can be configured as either a source or sink. Testing has been done using two configurations: SITL & a RaspberryPi + Navio2. The *source* should be started before the *sink*. ### SITL Sensor Hub for SITL works similar to GPS for SITL i.e. it uses a pipe (see `sitl_shub.cpp`). `sitl_shub.cpp` creates secondary instances of `AP_SensorHub` and its components to act as the *source*. In other words it does similar work to the `SensorHub_Source` vehicle type. The data is then sent via the pipe to the *sink*. #### Configure `./waf configure --board sitl --sensorhub-sink` #### Build `./waf --target bin/arducopter` #### Run The easiest way to run SITL is to use `autotools.py`. For example: `./Tools/autotest/autotest.py fly.ArduCopter` ### Navio2 ![navio2](https://docs.emlid.com/navio2/dev/img/pinout.png) #### Hardware Setup The Navio2's UART shown in the diagram is configured as a loopback. Simply connect the TX->RX pin. The UART is by default configured to run at 1152000 baud. This parameter still requires more testing as the read/write rates evolve with the protocol development. #### Configure - Source `./waf configure --board navio2 --sensorhub-source` - Sink `./waf configure --board navio2 --sensorhub-sink` #### Build - Source `./waf --target bin/sensorhub_source` - Sink `./waf --target bin/arducopter` #### Run Sensor Hub is currently configured to use UART F. We set UART F to use the Navio2's UART (i.e. `/dev/ttyAMA0`). - Source `./sensorhub_source -F /dev/ttyAMA0` - Sink `./arducopter -F /dev/ttyAMA0` ##### Debug Depending on the debugging options configured you can get output that looks like the following: - Source ``` AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Written: 56006 bytes/s AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Write: 2237 packets/s AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Write Error (count): 0 AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Write Error (missed bytes): 0 ``` - Sink ``` AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Read: 56550 bytes/s AP_SensorHub_IO_FD - Read : 2248 packets/s AP_SensorHub - decode Id: Gyro Avg: 3 (us) // This is processing time to decode a packet. AP_SensorHub - decode Id: Accel Avg: 3 (us) AP_SensorHub - decode Id: Compass Avg: 4 (us) AP_SensorHub - decode Id: Baro Avg: 3 (us) AP_SensorHub - decode Id: GPS Avg: 6 (us) ``` ## Remaining Work The infrastructure for this functionality is implemented. The following are some remaining work items to make the sensor hub architecture fully featured: - **SensorHub Read Thread**: Currently the read is done as part of the timer callback. To further reduce latency `AP_HAL` needs to be extended to support the notion of a thread. The IO's read can then be run as an independent thread. - **Time Profiling**: In-depth profiling metrics for Pixhawk + Companion Computer. - **Refactor Baro & GPS**: Baro and GPS are slightly different from INS or MAG in that the libraries do not "notify" to the frontend on raw samples. Instead the data is pushed only when the frontend's `update()` is called. These two sensors should be refactored so the all components are symmetric. - **Protocol Format Optimization** - **RCInput**: Support for RCInput Message - **RCOutput**: Support for RCOutput Message - **Parameter Configuration**: Support for parameter configuration from Sink->Source.

Title: Plane Improve quadplane landing transition velocity profile
Body: We have been flying a lot in strong wind lately and this is really exposing the limitations of the current hover transition decel algorithm that is used in auto missions. The current algorithm sets the target speed during decel to decrease linearly with distance from the landing point -> this transforms to ```a âˆ v^2``` which assumes the vehicle decelerates primarily with aerodynamic drag This initially seems like a strong implementation. However some significant limitations become clear in practice-> -v in this algorithm is ground-speed when drag is ```âˆ airspeed^2``` the result is the vehicle can not achieve the target decel when approaching a landing point with a strong tailwind -the transition waypoint must be positioned based on the worst case tailwind conditions this results in unnecessarily long transitions when approaching with a headwind -using an ```a âˆ v^2``` target velocity curve leaves a very long tail on the curve ie: the vehicle spends a long time at very low ground speed decelerating very slowly to cover the last portion of the distance to the landing point. The algorithm I'm proposing using implements a linear deceleration curve starting from a calculated distance from the landing point. This has the following effects: - The transition way-point just needs to be placed a sufficient distance from the landing point and the deceleration curve is not significantly affected by the waypoint placement unless the waypoint is placed too close for the Q_Transition_decel to allow the vehicle to stop in time - Deceleration is less in the first portion of the decel - allowing the target to be achieved and less alt to be gained especially during tailwind approaches - Deceleration is much higher in the last portion of the curve when the multi-copter can pitch back and use the stalled wing as a brake without gaining altitude. This massively decreases the time spent utilising lift from the multi rotor props before descending resulting in both lower and more consistent utilisation of the hover battery during landing. As an example we have a log of transition decel where out vehicle is approaching at 34m/s (strong tailwind) airspeed 25m/s with max pitch set to 10degrees. The last waypoint is 300m from the landing point. In this case the decel curves looks as follows: - first 15s is spent at full 10 degrees pitch up achieving a decel of 2m/s/s getting the speed down to 3m/s ~30m from the landing target having gained 13m (the vehicle never actually achieves the desired decel rate during this period) - a further 10s is spent covering the last ~30m to the landing target at very low speed - this whole (quite messy) sequence takes 300m and 25s With the new algorithm 2m/s/s gives a stopping distance of 289m and stopping time of 17s. The advantage here is that you are in a controlled decel with no risk of overshooting/ taking a large amount of extra time to position. The big advantage however comes when you switch the wind direction around with the same waypoint setup-> If we switch the wind around from 9m/s tail to 9m/s head on this sample mission the vehicle will take a full 60s to cover the 300m transition distance with the current algorithm with lift provided from the hover motors during the entire period. -By comparison this new algorithm would cover the 300m in just 21s with hover thrust required for only the last 9s

Title: AP_Common Add header in AP_FWVersion to allow binary parser
Body: This patch allows ArduPilot binaries to be identified without the necessity of any outside encapsulation (such as `apj`) or running the binary. In other words this patch tries to answer the following question: "Given an ArduPilot linux binary how do you *safely* tell which version board and vehicle it was built for ?" Helps #15370 - Add an `uint64_t` header to allow easy detection of struct in ArduPilot binaries - Add an `uint16_t` version for the struct - MSB is for major release compatibility break - LSB for minor version no compatibility break - Add pointer size variable to allow decode of pointers - Add vehicle type information - Add board type and subtype to allow hardware identification - Set type of fw_type to `uint8_t` since enum is declared as int but exist inside `uint8_t` space - Organize struct to be packed inside 32/64bits system

Title: Added support for external AHRS systems
Body: This adds support for external AHRS systems providing key sensors as well as a full AHRS solution. It is activated by setting AHRS_EKF_TYPE=11 and operates similarly to the existing EKF type 10 for SITL Initially this only supports the VectorNav VN-300 which is a high end AHRS system with dual-GPS. As we add more external AHRS systems we will need to do a frontend/backend split in AP_ExternalAHRS This is WIP and is pending a test flight. It initially uses a fixed config for the VN-300 which gives state estimation at 50Hz making it suitable for fixed wing and rovers but not copters. Addition of config options for a 400Hz solution will come in the future The backend provides drivers for GPS compass baro and IMU as well as an AHRS solution. So the external AHRS can be used as a source of sensors for the internal EKF or can be used for the whole state solution or both. Title: Answer to the ultimate question of life the universe and everything
Body: ... and the build size diff with master is This PR allow to automate the diff size reporting with master branch for CI and local build. It uses the build.binaries from autotest to fill a `firmware_sizes.json` that contains each vehicle build summary and serves it on autotest.ardupilot.org. The json file is create on same time as our database file. It got the following schema : ``` build_json = [{ board.lower(): {vehicle.lower(): {"text": text "data": data "bss": bss}} }] ``` A script is added : `diff_size_master.py` It allow to print diff size with master for a board. It tries to get the `firmware_sizes.json` from autotest.ardupilot.org first on failure it tries to look on the local buildlogs directory for the `firmware_sizes.json` file. With the data from master it makes a size diff with the data from the board binaries that should be in build/BOARD_NAME/bin. Testing: This PR can be tested by using `Tools/scripts/build_binaries.py --tags latest` to create the `firmware_sizes.json` locally into the buildlogs directory. Then using `Tools/scripts/diff_size_master.py -b fmuv2` for fmuv2 for example and it should print something like : ``` Binary text data bss total --------------- ------ ------ ------ ------- arducopter-heli +0.42% 0.00% 0.00% +0.35% ardusub +1.62% 0.00% +0.00% +1.32% arduplane +0.48% 0.00% -0.00% +0.39% ardurover +0.63% 0.00% -0.00% +0.51% antennatracker +0.57% 0.00% 0.00% +0.45% arducopter +0.41% 0.00% 0.00% +0.34% ``` You can also test the remote json downloading by using a simple file server from the buildlogs directory : ``` cd PATH_TO_Buildlogs_directory python3 -m http.server 8888 ``` to create a local server for the buildlogs directory on port 8888 Then replace the url in `Tools/scripts/diff_size_master.py` by "http://localhost:8888/firmware_sizes.json" and launch back `Tools/scripts/diff_size_master.py -b fmuv2` Once this will be on our server the next step will be to allow some CI build to use the diff script to report the diff size. Mitigation: This solution will increase the traffic on our server if CI use it but it shouldn't be much as the json file will be small (a few kb). To further improve traffic we could gz the json file and downloading it only once on CI startup phase to prevent multiple download. Another solution would be to put the json file for each board/vehicle into https://firmware.ardupilot.org/Rover/latest/ for example. That would reduce the traffic as the downloaded json would be minimal. We got a build database but I don't feel safe to allow remote access to it to get the lastest build summary. It could be done securely on CI with secret but would leave an open door on our server and need proper database management

Title: Add flake8 checking to CI tests
Body: This adds a step in our CI testing that checks Python files pass flake8 tests. Only files including a special `AP_FLAKE8_CLEAN` marker are checked for cleanliness. I've added `AP_FLAKE8_CLEAN` to the new CI script itself(!) and to `autotest.py` after tidying it up (again). I expect more to grow this marker as they're cleaned up. It checks `.py` files which are staged (for either create or modify) with flake8 and fails the commit if they are not compliant. This can stop bad Python getting into your commits in the first place. Title: Reset yaw mode to default when exting planck
Body: This PR sets the auto_yaw mode to default whenever a planck mode is exited. This prevents the current yaw mode from latching causing issues in the new mode if the new mode doesn't set it's own yaw mode. Specifically since the payload yaw control architecture requires the yaw mode to be AUTO_YAW_FIXED then if the user changes to stabilize the yaw mode will remain in AUTO_YAW_FIXED and the user will not have control of yaw. This PR fixes that by changing to the default yaw mode which gives the user yaw control (yaw control is given to user in stabilize in all auto yaw modes except AUTO_YAW_FIXED)

Title: Add option to param_parse py to emit SITL only parameters
Body: Our SITL parameter documentation (essentially anything under `SIM_`) is very poor. Partly this is due to poor tooling (but mostly due to apathy). This is an attempt to fix the former given recent fixes for the latter. It adds a "--sitl" option to `param_parse.py`. If that is not set then the tool's output is byte-for-byte for current master's. If it *is* set then we skip any parameter which doesn't have an annotation of ` // @HAL: SITL` as one of its fields and we end up with an (JSON) output file like this: ``` { "Copter": { "SIM_BARO_GLITCH": { "Description": "user-settable 1st-barometer glitch" "DisplayName": "Baro Glitch" "HAL": "SITL" "Units": "m" "User": "Advanced" } "SIM_BARO_RND": { "Description": "amount of (evenly-distributed) noise injected into the 1st baro" "DisplayName": "Baro Noise" "HAL": "SITL" "Units": "m" "User": "Advanced" } "SIM_GRPE_ENABLE": { "Description": "Allows you to enable (1) or disable (0) the gripper servo simulation" "DisplayName": "Gripper servo Sim enable/disable" "HAL": "SITL" "User": "Advanced" "Values": { "0": "Disabled" "1": "Enabled" } } "SIM_GRPE_PIN": { "Description": "The pin number that the gripper emp is connected to. (start at 1)" "DisplayName": "Gripper emp pin" "HAL": "SITL" "Range": { "high": "15" "low": "0" } ``` This might be suitable for including in the "wiki" at https://ardupilot.org/dev/docs/simulation-2.html I have a slight preference here for NOT adding this argument to `param_parse.py` and simply including the extra information in the metadata. This has the advantage of simplicity but has the disadvantage that until tools catch up the user interfaces might be cluttered by the extra parameters. For example in MAVProxy we might need to filter out ` // HAL: SITL` parameters unless `--sitl` has been passed on the command-line. Another example would be the Wiki which would need to do the splitting as part of building the Wiki. At the moment Tracker's Wiki actually does have some SITL parameters in it: https://ardupilot.org/antennatracker/docs/parameters.html#sim-grpe-parameters @brunoolivieri what do you think about the concept of splitting the parameter data based on `HAL`? @meee1 how would this work in with MP? I'm guessing you'd prefer everything in the one file with the extra annotations?

Title: Tools scripts Add PIE support in firmware_version_decoder
Body: Calculate pointer offset for PIE (Position Independent Executables) binaries. A PIE binary can have a pointer pointing to: 0x0014a700 ``` 0014a700 6c 65 73 73 20 74 68 61 6e 20 46 45 4e 43 45 5f |less than FENCE_| 0014a710 52 41 44 49 55 53 00 00 46 65 6e 63 65 73 20 69 |RADIUS..Fences i| 0014a720 6e 76 61 6c 69 64 00 00 4d 61 72 67 69 6e 20 69 |nvalid..Margin i| 0014a730 73 20 6c 65 73 73 20 74 68 61 6e 20 69 6e 63 6c |s less than incl| ``` But the correct pointer address is: 0x0013a700 ``` 0013a700 6f 6e 00 00 41 72 64 75 53 75 62 20 56 34 2e 32 |on..ArduSub V4.2| 0013a730 41 72 64 75 53 75 62 20 56 34 2e 32 2e 30 64 65 |ArduSub V4.2.0de| 00146680 73 69 6e 67 20 41 72 64 75 50 69 6c 6f 74 00 00 |sing ArduPilot..| 001466a0 52 41 4d 3a 20 25 75 0a 00 00 00 00 41 72 64 75 |RAM: %u.....Ardu| ``` The PR uses `elftools` to calculate the pointer offset based on `PT_LOAD` (Loadable segment) `p_vaddr` (Virtual address of the segment in memory) and `p_offset` (Offset of the segment in the file image). References: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executable_and_Linkable_Format

Title: build switch to gcc 10 2 1 for master builds
Body: This adds support for having a different compiler for different build tags. It switches the build of 'latest' on the build server to the 10.2.1 compiler while leaving beta and stable releases as our current 6.3.1 compiler. The 10.2.1 compiler has several advantages: - saves about 10k of flash on F4 boards - slightly faster code (lower sched misses on CubeBlack) - better warnings (already found one real bug see #18106 ) - support for newer C++ features I flew 10.2.1 on a plane yesterday and @MichelleRos flew it on a copter To use the new compiler with build_binaries.py you need to setup a $HOME/arm-gcc directory on the system with a link to the compiler with link name "g++-10.2.1" for example: g++-10.2.1 -> gcc-arm-none-eabi-10-2020-q4-major The new compilers are here: https://firmware.ardupilot.org/Tools/STM32-tools/ we should also think about -ffast-math which would save us another 10k of flash on F4 @khancyr we are going to need new VMs for 10.2 compiler I think. Ideally it would have both 6.3.1 and 10.2.1 in $HOME/arm-gcc with links like this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/831867/126917918-32a7c3aa-577f-428b-b037-ee8b71a838dd.png) This PR builds on: https://github.com/ArduPilot/ardupilot/pull/18122 https://github.com/ArduPilot/ChibiOS/pull/31

Title: Linux OBAL Board
Body: Open Board Architecture for Linux OBAL is a raspberry pi Linux-based Ardupilot FCB. The vision is to provide that: - Is a simple board that is easy to solder and assembled at home. - Can be customized and upgraded easily. - Acts as a developing and/or test platform to enable developers engineer & hobbyist who are interested in understanding Ardupilot hardware/software. - Complete Open-Source Hardware/Software and works on native Ardupilot code with no extra drivers.
